comments.commentBody:
"Are you all really ready to take THAT risk..."

— “joherz” of Bangor, Me. (via G. Schmidt)
————————————

When the proposed solution to the hysterically stated risk is to levy a massive carbon tax upon the citizens of presently bankrupt western nations and transfer that money to carbon speculators/traders and third world despots and their cronies, then yes, I am prepared to accept the consequences of not frittering away resources needed to develop new non-carbonaceous energy technologies and sources.

Richard Feynman's wish for all aspiring scientist graduates:
http://bit.ly/CHGmZ

"So I have just one wish for you--the good luck to be somewhere where you are free to maintain the kind of integrity I have described, and where you do not feel forced by a need to maintain your position in the organization, or financial support, or so on, to lose your integrity. May you have that freedom."

Gavin ...

If the down blanket you speak of is so warm and getting warmer, why do GISS do things like this?

http://c3headlines.typepad.com...

http://c3headlines.typepad.com...

Best Wishes

One more thing -

those who worry that we hate our children (joherz) or that "it's too late" (Peter Gleick; thank you, Lee Schipper for drawing attention to additional lunacy) should remember what the world did when (some internationally inspired and financed) genocides were carried out.

Poor people value their children more than the rich people profess to. They know they have to save themselves and their children first, no matter what. Let the rich beat their breasts about saving their own grandchildren or the whole world's; all they really care about is their own fame and money.

It seems to me, as simplistic as this may sound, that this could have been avoided if the administration took less of a "market-based" approach. Sigh, but people on both sides squandered any opportunity for universal health care.

Let me begin by stating the obvious. A single-payer government plan could have eliminated the concerns this reporting presents. I am sure plenty of writers will say that.
Let me add another obvious statement. A piece of legislation that was so huge was bound to carry loopholes you could drive a truck through and why shouldn't some people run out and buy that truck?
Lastly, because significant aspects of this legislation do not take effect until 2014 isn't that giving everybody a running chance to do what they like before then, prepare their defenses, and then challenge the government to take them on.
My mother used to say, "Oh what a web we weave when first we practice to deceive" and patients and taxpayers and government are all finding out that what was supposed to be health care reform has become a tenacious web that grows stronger at the expense of what the American people should have had...single payer, government health care.

i had quite a different opinion. i found the puzzle to be very challenging, even though i do consider myself an expert solver. part of it is that the theme, while overt, was very unhelpful to me, because i don't know (or really, care) much about food. this puzzle took me longer to solve than monday, tuesday, and wednesday... combined. and that's even with the aid of the wonderful applet.

typically i get about 10 answers on my first pass through an acrostic. on a "ridiculously easy" one (and there have been some), i get more than half. this time i had 5 (SMOOTHIE, IMPORTED, NIGHT OWL, SHARING, EPICURE). that was enough to eventually crack it, but i certainly did not feel that my intelligence was insulted or that it wasn't "worth doing." any hex puzzle contains delicious morsels that make it well worth doing. i'm still in awe over their amazing WSJ variety cryptic this week, but the acrostic has its pearls too.

How many times must the obvious be repeated? Transferring resources from the dynamism, discipline, and innovation of markets to a "stimulus" program (= allocation of resources by a corrupt, inefficient and blinkered government) DOES NOT STIMULATE ANYTHING.

Americans just don't seem to understand the conservative "don't do anything" mentality doesn't prevent things from happening on their own with totally unintended consequences. Is that that complicated?

So $800B was inadequate, but $1.2T would have been enough to give the economy "traction"?  Perhaps in a future post you could explain the mechanism by which the additional $400B would have made the difference between a double dip recession and a glorious Keynesian recovery.

Not another post claiming that if only the "stimulus" had been $1200 billion instead of $800 billion, everything would have been fine. Bill Anderson has a rebuttal here:

http://krugman-in-wonderland.blogspot.com/

Krugman has been insisting that the reason the economy is in a funk is because the Obama administration pushed through an $800 billion "stimulus" instead of a $1.2 trillion spending package. Yes, that his PK's argument: for lack of $400 billion to be spent on political pet projects, the entire economy is sinking. And never mind that this $400 billion is elsewhere, in the omnibus budget, in cash for clunkers, and the like.

There is no model, theory, or logic that says that if a policy implemented X, which causes unemployment to rise Y and when implemented at a level of 2X was observed to cause unemployment to rise 2Y, will somehow cause unemployment to improve when implemented at a 3X lvel. The economy is NOT a "chasm to be leaped".

Krugman now insists that Benanke's inflation will give the economy "traction," as if an economy is a machine that just needs a push from monetary authorities to move on its own.

Over the last decade, people borrowed too much and misdirected capital too much. Partly because government redirected too many resources to residential housing. Partly because government encouraged too much people to borrow money they could not return. Partly because changes in the Glass-Steagle Act make less clear what would benefit from government bailout. Partly because the Fed kept interest rates too low for too long. Republicans and Democrat alike are responsible, as "progressivism" is a mental disease that infects both.

And so we had a collapse. Which was bad enough. But that collapse was made far more consequential because government refused to allow the failed components of the economy to "lquidate". Instead of having successful auto producers (Ford) by up assets of failed auto producers (GM), "progressives" stepped in, used productive assets to bail out failed management, violated laws to give their cronies benefits, and dragged down the economy further.

And then came Obamacaer, which is destroying jobs before our eyes, even as over 100 firms and unions scramble to get "waivers". And hgher taxes on retained earnings that would otherwise be used to create jobs.

And now Krugman advocates "theft" of 28% of everyone's dollar-denominated savings as a "fix". Regime uncertainty is causing $1 trillion (or is it $2 trillion) to lie fallow. And in this post, yet another series of crony-driven spending programs.

What Paul, is 20% real unemployment not enough for you? You want to try for 30%? You know, we got that the last time we had "progressives" doing "bold persistent experimentation", in the 1930's.

When did this brand of politics start, whereby the President doesn't dare say anything unless it polls well or it has a chance of getting through congress? There is a fundamental misreading of the public perception by the POTUS and his staff because it is clear that they believe in polls and election results as some sort of mystic wisdom.

It is still clear as day to me that the POTUS and his staff are so fundamentally misreading the public desire. Even if they believe what they believe, there's really no excuse except cowardly self-preservation to avoid saying repeatedly what needs to be done, unless they really don't believe it either.

Consumption taxes are regressive but regressiveness is relative to the disparity in income levels of the taxpaying public.  Sweden has a massive middle class and much less disparity between the rich and poor than, for example, in the U.S.  Thus Sweden's high VAT, at 25%, is not so regressive.

Bernanke is right. Dr. Krugman is right. The Democrats in the Senate and House are right. And it is right and proper and necessary to keep fighting because the other side is determined to shut down the Middle Class if we do not.

The battle is on....(www.populistdaily.com)...and if you let your guard down and stop swinging, you will only get more shots to the chin, more unemployed, more outsourced jobs, more Right Wing propaganda.

It is a fight between political systems...total control of society by a very wealthy few or control by the broader majority. Thus far, the rich are winning.

If it makes you feel any better (and I'm sure it won't) I don't think there was a chance in hell of him affecting policy a year ago either.  We've certainly gone from bad to worse, but bad was still too much

Why is it too late to use the majority in Congress till January to slam some stimulus through? I know 'the American people' (whoever they are) supposedly want both parties to cooperate and work for the good of the country but that just isn't happening. The Democrats have tried to reach across the aisle to no avail. Now the Greedy Old People have stated they are going to repeal the health care legislation by starving it to death. Why not add a few more spending bills that are beneficial to the middle class so we can have a real showdown in 2012?
Will the real American people choose a continuation of the insane 'Trickle Down' money grab for one percent of the population or will they vote for policies that will benefit a vast majority and make the country fiscally sound? It is time for the real majority to make themselves heard.

This is an anguished plea for help from an academic who is coming to the horrifying realization that even decades of cloistered, academic research is no substitute for real world experience in understanding how markets work. And now Bernanke is desperate for someone, anyone, to rescue him lest he have to admit that his entire professional career has been wrong-headed.

Take a good look Paul because this will be you in a few years when the bond bubble, which you so vehemently deny exists, bursts and plunges the country into an even deeper crisis than in 2008. God save us from the ministrations of Princeton professors.
The Ben-Bernank really messed up on this one.  But then again he is a Republican.
Yep. The Democrats played it safe and got killed anyway. They should have just gone for it. Stupid Blue Dogs.
no, your ire should be aimed at politicians, not BB.  BB is doing the best he can with the morones in congress who are too incompetent to succeed in the private sector.
I am sure that Ben Bernanke will be able to find a pony in the pile of Republican suggestions on how to fix the economy.

You are too pessimistic PK.

Congress could enact a payroll tax holiday such as Dr. Roubini has proposed and that could go a long way toward reducing unemployment. Also, Congress could extend the Bush tax cuts for 2 years and ignore the Deficit Commission recommendations, both of which would be Keynesian moves.

True, there won't be any more "shovel-ready" bullet trains funded, but that wasn't stimulative anyway. Maybe another home buyers' tax credit will pass which would be helpful.
Come January Republican governors will throw the economy back into recession by blindly gutting state budgets, all in the name of deficit reduction. Spare us from false savings!

The authorities have a simple choice: Crash the bond market or crash the dollar. Refusing to take the hit will only crash both.
There is no exit from objective mathematical reality.
There is no Twilight Zone, no world of perpetual state of illusion.
Reality bites.
The banks lost all of the money in the world; the people cannot cover such large losses in this lifetime.
Get over it...
Of course "waiting until it is too late" is a good way to refuse to do something without openly refusing to do it. You can later say that you "hoped to do it."
